Jun 07

Whirlwind Maritime Tour

No comments yet

Leaving from Halifax, the first stop on our five-day tour was in Truro at the Millbrook Cultural and Heritage Centre.  Here, we learned about the Mi’kmaq people and enjoyed the superb multimedia presentation and exhibits.

Following a scenic drive to Cape Breton, we stopped for lunch and a view at the Cove Motel, prior to exploring the Ceilidh Trail.  A quick stop in Inverness to visit the Cabot Links resort and “pro-shop” which is, as they say, “Built by Dreamers for Dreamers”.

We toured the Cabot Trail, during which, the Cabot Trail Relay was underway.  This is a gruelling 185 mile/276.33 km, 17 stage relay race through some of the most beautiful scenery in the world.  This year, there were over 70 teams competing so runners where everywhere!  I think I’d prefer to drive it than run it.

We stopped in Neils Harbour at the Chowder House – reviews tell us it just might be the best Chowder in eastern Canada!  With super views of the Ocean and delicious chowder, I may just have to agree with the reviews!

Despite the mountains being shrouded in heavy mist and clouds, our Cabot Trail journey did allow us to see a Mother Moose nursing her calf on MacKenzie Mountain – What a treat!  We stayed in Baddeck so had the opportunity to introduce ourselves to Alexander Graham Bell and his wife, Mabel.

Leaving Nova Scotia by ferry, we headed to Prince Edward Island – the Gentle Island!  No trip here would be complete without a New Glasgow Lobster dinner.  Wonderful.

We visited Charlottetown (the Birthplace of Confederation), Anne of Green Gables in Cavendish and strolled along the beautiful beach and sidewalks of Prince Edward Island National Park.  We spent some time in the Brackley Beach area visiting the Great Canadian Soap Company (specializes in goats milk products) and at the Dunes Gallery and Café.

We left PEI by way of the Confederation Bridge, briefly stopping in Shediac to see the “giant lobster” then spent the remainder of the afternoon at Hopewell Cape.  We enjoyed a private guided tour of the famous “Flower Pots” of the Bay of Fundy before heading to Chateau Moncton for the night.

A fantastic trip with many unique sights.

Jun 03

Who knew?

No comments yet

I recently had the pleasure of touring a wonderful family around our great Province.  During our chats, I discovered they were Jewish so shared a ‘little known’ story with them.  I want to share it with you also.  The following was written by Michael Steinitz in 1998 about a tiny community in Cape Breton called Dingwall…Enjoy!

I was doing what my family enjoyed calling my “streetwalker thing”.  Halifax has never had much of a problem with terrorists, but like most Israeli towns it [the Israeli town I was located in] had instituted a “Civil Guard”, which some wags also called the “Old Crocks Brigade”, or worse.  This involved members of the citizenry who would once each month voluntarily undertake armed nighttime street patrols in groups of two, under the supervision of the chronically undermanned police.  The rate of terrorist attacks was too small to show a measurable difference, but the rate of nighttime burglaries had shown a satisfying decrease – if one ignored the almost equal increase in the rate of daytime burglaries.  Among other benefits I got to spend long hours in conversation – with my partner and on the walkie-talkie (known in Hebrew as HaMotorola) to the police.  At least my fluency improved, if not the delicacy of my language.

My partner that night was an old sea-dog.  He had retired from the Israeli Navy at about 65, after a life at sea – at first in the merchant marine, and then in the Israeli Defence Forces.

His first question was essentially “where’re ya from kid?”, to which I dutifully replied “Nova Scotia” in my best Hebrew, swallowing what little remained of my professional dignity after my daily encounter with the admittedly bright, but sometimes disconcertingly abrupt and direct Israeli students I was teaching.

“I’ll bet I know a place in Nova Scotia you’ve never been”, he then continued.

 

Feeling my pride at stake, I replied “try me!”

 

“Dingwall!” he said.

 

“My favourite place”, I replied honestly, having spent several weekends in this wonderful spot every summer with my wife and children since arriving in Nova Scotia in 1973 from points west.  It is an idyllically situated little village a few miles off the Cabot Trail in Cape Breton, with mountains descending straight into the sea, sandy beaches, the rough North Atlantic, almost no people, and our very favourite motel, which had only four spotless cottages.  “But how did you ever get there?” I asked, and thereby hangs the following tale.

In 1948 Israel was invaded by six Arab armies and found itself with very few arms and fewer friends.  Among the desperate needs was the need for vehicles, especially Jeeps.  But no-one would sell the newborn country any Jeeps, for fear of angering the Arab states.  Finally, Canada agreed to sell Israel 48 used World-War Two surplus Jeeps, but under very strict conditions: no-one must know of the sale.  No-one must even be able to see the delivery taking place.  Thus the delivery would not be permitted to take place in Halifax, or even Sydney in cape Breton, as the risk of someone seeing it taking place would be too great.  It would be Dingwall, Nova Scotia or nothing.  Take it or leave it, and, of course, as beggars can’t be choosers, Israel took it.

My partner was then the captain of a small freighter, and it fell upon him to pick up the Jeeps.  He was told that he must enter Dingwall harbour through a narrow space in the stone breakwaters, at night, without lights, and that he must be at sea before first light in the morning.

“Do you know what ‘meshuggah’ is?” he asked rhetorically.  “Meshuggah is someone who takes a big ship into Dingwall harbour at night without lights – that’s a meshuggah!”  But he got his load of Jeeps, he was at sea before morning, “hightailing it for the Med”, as he put it, and Dingwall had played its part in the history of Israel.  It may have been very important.

 

Postscript: I recently heard from a friend of a friend that “Of course I know about those Jeeps – those were the Jeeps that Moshe Dayan used to take the town of Ramle, in one of the decisive battles of the War of Independence!”

May 30

War Bride Reunion

No comments yet

As war brides returned to Halifax for a weekend reunion, I had the pleasure of showing some of them around the area in between their celebrations at Pier 21.

Our first day tour was along the scenic South Shore coastline visiting Hubbards, Chester, Mahone Bay and Lunenburg.  Not only did they get to see some beautiful sights, but also enjoyed shopping in some boutique Nova Scotian stores.

No trip to Nova Scotia would be complete without visiting the Bay of Fundy, so day two saw a leisurely drive to the Annapolis Valley to the small fishing village of Hall’s Harbour where everyone could see both high and low tides of the Bay of Fundy.  We also enjoyed a unique tour of a lobster pound.

While the tide changed, we had plenty of time to visit and explore Blomidon Look-Off, the Acadian Deportation Cross in Grand Pre and also Lucketts Vineyards in Gaspereau Valley.

With the Bay of Fundy’s highest tides in mind, we visited Salmon River in Truro so they could see the unique tidal bore arrive in ‘full force’.

   

A rainy Monday led us to change the itinerary slightly and we decided to spend the day in Halifax visiting some of the historic sites.  We began with a trip to Citadel Hill to witness the noon-gun salute (which on this day, became a 21-gun salute to honour Queen Victoria’s birthday) and continued on to visit the 1917 Halifax Explosion sites and the Titanic Cemetery.  As the drizzle subsided, we headed to Peggy’s Cove for somewhat of a foggy and damp vista then warmed up in the “Sou’Wester” restaurant with a lunch of lobster rolls.

Our final day of touring began with a ferry ride from Halifax to Woodside, thus allowing the war brides a superb view of Pier 21.  Pier 21 was their initial point of entry into Canada so many years ago and undoubtedly stirred a few emotions.  From Woodside, we toured along the Eastern Shore to Fisherman’s Cove and Lawrencetown Beach before returning to their hotel.

A fun-filled few days full of celebrations, shopping and sight-seeing – Thank you Ladies!

May 24

And then…the bus broke down!

No comments yet

On May 8, our tour began at Lord Nelson Hotel in Halifax as we collected 26 Dalhousie Business students (including 3rd year students on an “exchange program” with a University in Israel) and two of their professors.    Our destination was Hall’s Harbour so they could experience the Bay of Fundy’s high and low tides.

On arrival at Halls Harbour, the tide was almost “dead low” – perfect to compare with the high tide later in the day.  Next stop on our itinerary was the Blomidon Look-Off – unfortunately “Mother-Nature” didn’t want to cooperate and blanketed the “look-off” with heavy fog!

We meandered down the mountain, through the town of Wolfville to view “the Landscapes of Grand Pre”.  The professors took a “class picture”  . . . everyone was in great spirits!  Although closed, we visited Grand Pre National Historic site and toured the grounds before heading back to Wolfville to lunch at Joe’s Food Emporium.

Immediately following lunch, someone suggested we stop for an ice cream at Hennigars  (Oh yes – that was me!). As always, this stop was a big hit, as was our next stop at Planter’s Ridge Winery.  They sampled three of the winery’s finest offerings and about a dozen bottles later, “climbed aboard the bus”.

Leaving Planter’s, our next destination was back to the Look-Off where hopefully Mother Nature would cooperate this time!  We passed by freshly plowed fields and on into Canning and then . . . the bus broke down!

The student’s took it in their stride – they made lemonade from “the lemon”!  They played games, socialized and walked to Canning’s Shipyard Park to await the arrival of a replacement bus.  It took about two hours for the bus to arrive from Halifax, fortunately weather-wise the sun was shining and the temperature was on the “mild-side”.

Once on the replacement bus, the decision was made to return to Halifax.  Unfortunately they never did get to see high tide in Halls Harbour.  Perhaps next time.

What a super group and great sports they all were!

May 19

Exploring PEI

No comments yet

Recently, myself, Ann (my wife) and driver Dave and his wife, Martha, hit the road to check out some new tours for 2016.

Leaving from Halifax, we headed towards Truro and the Millbrook Cultural and Heritage Centre. The Centre offers an innovative multimedia presentation of the rich history of the Mi’kmaw people, however, today it was closed so we continued on to Aulac, NB and turned off for the Confederation Bridge.

View of Confederation Bridge from Cape Jourimain

We briefly stopped at Cape Journiman to photograph the bridge. “The curved, 12.9 kilometre (8 mile) long bridge isthe longest in the world crossing ice-covered water, and more than a decade after its construction, it endures as one of Canada’s top engineering achievements of the 20th century”.

We stopped at Gateway Village – a picturesque shopping spot – gathered our maps and coffee and set off to explore Prince Edward Island.

Our first stop was at Seven Mile Bay so we could photograph the sheer immensity of the Confederation Bridge – truly a spectacular sight!

View of Bridge from Seven Mile Bay

Spring planting

We toured along Routes 1, 1A and 2 to Hunter River, passing tens of thousands of acres of freshly plowed farm land being prepared for potatoes, corn or soybean. Generally speaking, this was the constant scene as we toured around PEI – freshly plowed landscape.  No doubt this land will be vibrant and colourful in a few months.

Many of the PEI ‘tourist’ spots were closed (such as New Glasgow Lobster Dinner restaurant and PEI Preserves) but will shortly open for the season.

Our overnight accommodation was at Brackley Beach North Winds Resort with hosts Isaac MacPherson and his Father, Murray – Thanks Guys!

Just after we checked into the North Winds, I spied a FOX on the grounds!  PEI was famous for Silver Fox Farming but when those furs went of fashion, the fox farmers opened the cages and released their foxes into the “wild”, so it is not uncommon to see them.  As we returned from dinner we saw another fox along the side of the road – foxes, it appears, prefer chicken to rabbit …according to Dave who knows these things.

We headed for Charlottetown for dinner and ate at Papa Joe’s on University Avenue.

In the morning, following a great breakfast (thank you Isaac), Dave and I met with Mickey from Red Sand Tours.  We hope his team will be joining Blue Diamond Tours for shore excursions from Charlottetown.

After our check-out, we headed eastward towards Souris.   Souris is a Canadian port town in northeastern Kings County, Prince Edward Island. It’s located in an area famous for its beaches and potatoes (and amazing scenery), containing the majority of Prince Edward Island’s potato farmers.  

 We stopped in St Peters for photos – what a beautiful community!  We ultimately arrived at The Inn at Bay Fortune, owned by chef Michael Smith and his wife Charity.  We met and spoke with Charity who was excited to announce they have earned their 5 stars for this year.  (We have included this inn and their “feast” as part BDT’s Culinary Delights Tour).

Inn at Bay Fortune

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

View from Inn

Near the inn is the Government wharf – a super place to see boats and people landing their catches.

Bay of Fortune Wharf

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

We briefly stopped in Souris and explored the terminal for the ferry to Ile de la Madeleine (a five hour crossing one way) and the nearby lighthouse before heading back to Charlottetown.

Grape vines for Brandy

At Rollo Bay we stopped at “The Myriad View Artisan Distillery” and toured their vineyard.  Their grapes used for making “Brandy” – no wine here.  The distillery tour, I was told, takes about 15 minutes more or less and it’s free.  We couldn’t help but buy a product sample!   Arriving in Charlottetown, we lunched on the city’s waterfront, “Lobster on the Wharf “.

Lobster Lunch

Lobster on the wharf

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

After lunch, we enjoyed a brief tour through Charlottetown, drove through UPEI campus and then onto Route 2 to Hunter River and Kensington.  We continued on to Summerside then back to Gateway Village for our return journey to Halifax.

May 16

The CSS Tallahassee

No comments yet

 

Boardwalk at Fishermans Cove

Ann and I spent some exploring Fisherman’s Cove and the surrounding area. This is where the CSS Tallahassee performed an extraordinary feat through this narrow waterway to escape from Halifax during the US Civil war.  This is part of the story as told by the Maritime Museum of the Atlantic:

Under cover of darkness, August 19, 1864, the Confederate raider CSS Tallahassee slipped through Halifax Harbour’s Eastern Passage under the skilled pilotage of Jock Flemming. This act of both skilled seamanship and daring entered our Maritime history and became legend.

The Tallahassee Affair

The effects of the American Civil War extended far beyond the boundaries of the United States. Throughout Europe and British North America, the populace was divided in its sympathies despite government avowals of neutrality. In Halifax, there was a strong sympathy for the cause of the Confederacy, especially among businessmen who profited from commercial dealings with the Confederate states.

At dawn on August 18th, 1864, The Confederate Steamship Tallahassee, a raider from Wilmington, North Carolina, steamed into Halifax Harbour in hopes of replenishing her dwindling supply of coal. Tallahassee’s job as a raider had been to attack Union commercial shipping and, in the month preceding, under the command of Capt. John Taylor Wood, she had sunk or bonded over 30 Union vessels.

Under the British Neutrality Laws, Tallahassee’s stay in Halifax was limited to 24 hours or enough time to take on sufficient coal at Woodside to enable her to return to Wilmington, the nearest “friendly” port. The Lt. Governor of Nova Scotia allowed a further 24 hours for Tallahassee to ship a new mainmast to replace the one she had lost in a collision a week before.

When Capt. Wood heard reports of Union gunboats waiting off the harbour entrance for Tallahassee to leave, he sought the advice of one of the senior harbour pilots, “Jock” Flemming, on how best to elude the enemy. It was decided to attempt the Eastern Passage, a feat never before accomplished by a vessel the size of Tallahassee. At 0100 on Saturday, August 20, Tallahassee weighed anchor and, after an hour of skillful maneuvering, cleared the Passage and headed for the open sea.

The daring of Captain Wood and the skill of Jock Flemming became legend in Nova Scotia long after the event and today, the Tallahassee School in Eastern Passage commemorates the event.

Apr 18

Spring Road Trip

No comments yet

What does a tour operator do on a day off? One of his own tours of course!

Blue Diamond Tours recently created “Cajun Motherland” single and multi-day trips, so my wife and I decided to leisurely drive the single day trip.

A beautiful spring day, high tides forecast…we couldn’t have asked for better weather and dramatic scenery.

Our itinerary took us through Wolfville, with a stop at Hennigar’s Farm Market for ice cream (Can anyone resist doing this?). Following our farm market purchases, we drove over to Port Williams, located on the Cornwallis River, for a couple quick ‘pics’ of the Acadian Dykes (circa 1650) which follow along the banks of this Fundy tidal river.

Our next stop was Planter’s Ridge Winery, located on a former New England Planter farm, but more formerly, an Acadian farmstead. Following a purchase of a bottle of Tidal Bay wines and more ‘pics’, we headed back towards Halifax.

As we crossed the Gaspereau River, the incoming tide had filled it to “the brim”, and later, as we crossed the Avon River marshes, they were almost totally covered by the incoming tide. Quite a spectacular sight!

In Windsor, we visited the Park’s Canada Fort Edward Site (blockhouse), a fortress whose history is intertwined with the Expulsion of the Acadians in 1755. Standing proudly and steeped in history, it was the perfect ending to a wonderful spring road trip!

Nov 09

Best Practice Mission

No comments yet

Blue Diamond Tours (really me, Bob) participated in a Best Practice Mission sponsored by TIANS and Tourism Nova Scotia

“The mission was to focus on the Atlantic coastline between St. Margaret’s Bay and Shelburne, this mission will provide participants with an inside look at how to develop effective grassroots partnerships and marketable product offerings. Delegates will learn how to enhance their regional inventory of quality tourism experiences and identify potential supporters and collaborators. The mission itinerary will encompass a broad array of tourism businesses and organizations that have competitively positioned themselves as a destination or experience of choice.”

I did learn a lot about a lot of things and have a couple of exciting partnership/collaborative opportunities in the works for 2016. I identified new experiences to incorporated in Blue Diamond Tours’ 2016 offerings (ie: marketable product offerings) on the South Shore, the Gold Coast (Eastern Shore) and Cape Breton.

Look for these in early 2016.
